entries.text: Create internal cloud hosting solutions within Morgan Stanley. As a contributor on our budapest-based team, you will have responsibility to contribute not only to the code, but to the design and engineering of the full PaaS systems.
entries.title: Morgan Stanley Budapest Perl developer for cloud

entries.text: There are going to be 3 courses at YAPC::EU in Granada, Spain. At one of them you can learn how to use Angular JS together with Perl Dancer. Save 100 Euro by signing up before 14th August!
entries.title: Front-end with AngularJS, Back-end with Perl Dancer and MongoDB - Save 100 Euro.

entries.author: david_farrell
entries.text: David's monthly curated round-up of new distributions on CPAN, including his personal choice for new module of the month, which comes from Damian Conway.
entries.title: What's new on CPAN - July 2015

entries.author: david_golden
entries.text: David announced the first release candidate for the Perl MongoDB driver, version 1.0.0. This is a "substantial rewrite" of the original Perl driver, so if you use MongoDB, they'd like you to kick the tyres, and perhaps a little bit more.
entries.title: Announcing the MongoDB Perl driver v1.0.0 Release Candidate

entries.author: aristotle_pagaltzis
entries.text: Aristotle has created Plack::Middleware::MockProxyFrontend to make it easier to test websites where the content served depends on the domain name.
entries.title: Developing virtualhost-aware PSGI applications

entries.author: olaf_alders
entries.text: This is a state of the HTTP::BrowserDetect nation from Olaf, who has been maintaining it for 5 years. He wants to let us know it's still very much actively maintained, and that he's keen to receive, and quick to act on, pull requests to keep the coverage update. And he also wants to shame those of us who are tardy at merging PRs, and rightly so.
entries.title: On the status of HTTP::BrowserDetect

entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.text: CPAN Day is August 16th, and celebrates the date of the first upload to CPAN in 1995. So this coming Sunday marks the 20th anniversary. Why not do something on/for CPAN Day?
entries.title: Do something for CPAN Day 2015

entries.author: miguel_prz
entries.text: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.
entries.title: NICEPERL's lists

entries.author: frew_schmidt
entries.text: Frew wrote a wee script using WWW::Kickstarter to watch a kickstarter project and let him know when an early bird offer came available (because an existing backer had cancelled).
entries.title: Perl ‚ù§ Kickstarter

entries.author: gabriele_mambrini
entries.text: Gabriele shares experiences getting a Catalyst app up and running on Heroku.
entries.title: Fun with Catalyst and Heroku

entries.author: david_bradford
entries.text: David talks through the multi_input function he wrote, so that scripts can take input from STDIN, one or more files, or a default input file. He also illustrates the use of the reverse builtin to invert a hash, which at least two long-term perl hackers weren't aware of.
entries.title: Accepting Input from Multiple Sources

entries.author: daniel_culver
entries.text: Daniel explains that a common task in bio informatics is to find instances of a pattern in a string. But you often can't use the obvious regexp approach, because you want to find overlapping occurrences of the pattern in the target string. He shows us his solution.
entries.title: Finding the index and number of occurrences of a pattern in a string

entries.author: mark_dominus
entries.text: Mark wrote a Perl version of a previous Haskell program using a list monad to solve a cryptarithm puzzle. In writing this I decided I should find out what a monad is. I found various pages declaring themselves to be simple explanations of monads, but I'm not sharing the links here, because I still don't understand monads :-)
entries.title: The list monad in Perl and Python

entries.author: sinan_unur
entries.text: Sinan tested Inline::CPP on Windows 8.1 and had some test failures. He steps us through the path to fixing them, which as you can guess from the title, came down to directory separators.
entries.title: Test failures and directory separators: Take N

entries.text: ActiveState address the question of what's going to happen to them given the sale of their Stackato (PaaS) business to HP.
entries.title: ActiveState: What's Next?

entries.author: makoto_nozaki
entries.text: Nozaki-san wonders whether there should be a (monetary) award for "best Perl application" each year, to try and make a bit more noise about successful Perl apps. He wants to hear what we think, so why not let him know?
entries.title: RFC: Perl software of the year award

entries.text: Notes from Stuart's talk to Sydney.PM about ways you can "spread the word" about Perl.
entries.title: Evangelizing Perl

entries.author: peter_rabbitson
entries.text: Ribasushi gave a lightning talk at YAPC:NA this year, and tweeted about the topic again this week. His message was: if there's something you don't like about a module, it's easy to let the author know by sending email to the RT mail alias. I thought it would be neat to have a bug email demultiplexor for CPAN, where we could email dist-name@bug.perl.org and it would check whether the dist has a specified bug tracker, using that if so, or RT otherwise. But Ribasushi pointed out that GitHub's T's & C's don't allow this kind of automatic bug submission.
entries.title: Make yourself heard

entries.author: david_golden
entries.text: David periodically publishes a chart that shows the dates of the Perl 5 stable releases; this one shows from 5.4 to the most recent 5.22. The thing that really stands out is the steady march of yearly releases from 5.12 onwards.
entries.title: Visualizing Perl 5 Release History ‚Äì 2015 edition

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: The slidecast Perl tutorial has passed 177 freely available episodes. Available on YouTube or downloadable from the Perl Maven site.
entries.title: Beginner Perl Maven video course

entries.author: jonathan_worthington
entries.text: Jonathan is taking the lead on the Great List Refactor, he fixed some issues related to our-scoped things inside roles, and a bunch of other thing besides.
entries.title: Fixing lots of RTs, digging into the GLR

entries.author: aaron_baugher
entries.text: Aaron took a Perl 5 script that he wrote ages ago, but has been using ever ince, and rewrote it in Perl 6. He talks through the new script, explaining it step by step. And it prompted some good discussion in the comments.
entries.title: Refactoring Very Old Perl 5 in Perl 6

entries.author: aaron_baugher
entries.text: Following on from an earlier blog post, and comment from Liz, Aaron compared the performance of index() with a regexp, and found that for his case index was 10 times faster than his best regexp, and 100 times faster than his first solution.
entries.title: Benchmarking index() and regex in Perl 6

entries.text: Aaron's shows how he made it easier to enter more exotic characters in Emacs, which you might need to do when you're programming in Perl 6.
entries.title: Using Unicode in Emacs for Perl 6

entries.author: dmitri_tikhonov
entries.text: Support for Perl 6 has been added to ctags; you can grab it from github. If you're not familiar with it, ctags is "a programming tool that generates an index (or tag) file of names found in source and header files of various programming languages", says Wikipedia.
entries.title: ctags now supports Perl 6

entries.text: A list of 11 things that men can do to support women in computing.
entries.title: Things That Men Can Do To Be Real Allies For Women In Computing

entries.author: caleb_cushing
entries.text: Inspired by a blog post by Jeff Atwood, Caleb put together of falsehoods that programmers sometimes believe about version numbers.
entries.title: Falsehoods programmers believe about versions

entries.text: A good discussion about some of the challenges faced on the move from senior developer to tech lead, and why not everyone who's good at the former will be good at the latter. He's written a lot about tech leads, so Patrick's blog is a good source of additional material if you're interested in the topic.
entries.title: Expert developers don't necessarily make the best tech leads

entries.text: David Loftesness was the director of engineering at twitter. This is his guide for evolving engineers into good managers.
entries.title: This 90-Day Plan Turns Engineers into Remarkable Managers

entries.text: "This guide is designed as an aid for beginners and experienced users to find specific tips and explore tools available within Postgres". It was written by Craig Kerstiens (with help from others), who also curates Postgres Weekly.
entries.title: Postgres Guide

entries.text: The rite of passage entering the land of AngularJS.
entries.title: TODO in AngularJS

entries.title: Automatic counter using AngularJS

header: There is a new version of the MongoDB driver coming for Perl 5, and David would like you to try out the first release candidate.
This Sunday, 16th August, is CPAN Day, and this year marks the 20th anniversary of the first upload to CPAN.
I still don't know what a monad is.
subject: CPAN Day is Sunday 16th August
